trans-unit.source: Specifies a set of standard access rights that correspond to operations common to most types of securable objects.
The <xref:System.Messaging.StandardAccessRights> class provides access rights for common operations, such as deleting, reading, and writing.
The precise meaning of each member is specific to the object type to which it is applied.
<xref:System.Messaging.StandardAccessRights> is one of two enumerations to which the <xref:System.Messaging.GenericAccessRights> enumeration maps extensive read, write, or execute abilities.
<xref:System.Messaging.StandardAccessRights> enables you to specify rights common to most objects, for example, deleting the object or reading a security descriptor.
Both <xref:System.Messaging.StandardAccessRights> and <xref:System.Messaging.MessageQueueAccessRights> provide a member for deleting a queue.
The needs of the application define which set of flags you use.
Combines `Delete`, `ReadSecurity`, `WriteSecurity`, `ModifyOwner`, and `Synchronize` access.
The right to delete the object.
The right to read the information in the object's security descriptor.
On Windows 2000 and Windows NT, the security descriptor contains the security information for a securable object.
It identifies the object's owner and primary group.
`Execute` is currently defined to equal `ReadSecurity`.
The right to change the owner in the object's security descriptor.
No access.
The right to read the information in the object's security descriptor.
`Read` is currently defined to equal `ReadSecurity`.
The right to read the information in the object's security descriptor.
Combines `Delete`, `ReadSecurity`, `WriteSecurity`, and `ModifyOwner` access.
The right to use the object for synchronization.
This enables a thread to wait until the object is in a specific state.
The right to read the information in the object's security descriptor.
`Write` is currently defined to equal `ReadSecurity`.
The right to modify the discretionary access control list (DACL) in the security descriptor.
The DACL controls access to the object.
Being able to write to the DACL gives the user the ability to set security for the object.
